questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
An organization is considering migrating resources to the cloud. The company does not plan to deploy Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute or site-to-site VPNs.
You need to identify which workloads you can migrate to the cloud.
Which workloads you can migrate to the cloud? To answer, drag the appropriate actions to the correct workloads. Each action may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

discussion.content: There it is in BLACK and WHITE.... Legacy Applications need to remain on Premises... Not Applications that manage Sensitive Data, Not Applications that require the use of a USB device.... this was another question that so many people were unclear about
This is correct
Key requirement is, “The company does not plan to deploy Microsoft Azure ExpressRoute or site-to-site VPNs.” This means no hybrid. Only private and public cloud.
A resposta esta correta

How about the first one "Migrate to Cloud":
You have a legacy application that requires connectovity with an on-premises data store

We have DATA GATEWAYS for data On-Prem?
yes correct

questions.question_text:
You are the desktop administrator for an organization.
You need to ensure that Office 365 ProPlus is installed on all employee computers.
Which three tools can you use to deploy Office 365 ProPlus? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
questions.answer_description:
Microsoft Intune allows you to to deploy Office 365 ProPlus applications to Windows 10 devices from the cloud.
System Center Configuration Manager allows you to deploy Office 365 ProPlus to client computers from a local source, using your Configuration Manager distribution points.
The Office Deployment Tool (ODT) allows you to deploy Office 365 ProPlus to client computers from the Office Content Delivery Network (CDN) or from a shared folder on your network.
Reference:
https://techcommunity.microsoft.com/t5/enterprise-mobility-security/deploying-office-365-proplus-with-microsoft-intune/ba-p/250292 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/DeployOffice/deploy-office-365-proplus-from-the-cloud https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/DeployOffice/deploy-office-365-proplus-from-a-local-source

discussion.content: ADE is correct

As três ferramentas que você pode usar para implantar o Office 365 ProPlus são:

A. Microsoft Intune
D. Gerenciador de configuração do System Center
E. Ferramenta de implantação do Office

I didnot find Intune 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/DeployOffice/plan-microsoft-365-apps

Choose how you want to deploy:

Deploy from a local source with Configuration Manager: Manage your deployment with Configuration Manager, and download and deploy Office from distribution points on your network.

Deploy from the cloud with the Office Deployment Tool: Manage your deployment with the ODT, and install Office on client devices directly from the Office CDN.

Deploy from a local source with the Office Deployment Tool: Manage your deployment with the ODT, and download and deploy Office from a local source on your network.

Self-install from the cloud: Manage your deployment from the Office portal and have your users install Office on their client devices directly from the portal.
ADE estão corretas.
ADE for sure
Correct
Correct answer

A, D, and E

The MSI install option is not available:
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/msoffice/forum/msoffice_o365admin-mso_dep365-mso_o365b/creating-a-msi-file-of-office-365-pro-plus/858b4359-025d-4c21-9c86-5eb5791372ad

Answer is correct

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/policy-and-compliance/information-rights-management?%20view=exchserver-2019&view=exchserver-2019
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/compliance/information-rights-management-in-exchange-online?view=o365-worldwide

Above links support the third row on Information rights

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/client-developer/exchange-web-services/ews-throttling-in-exchange

Custom throttling is to be done on the server

Sure, here is the translation of the previous responses in English:

To respond to the statements about the differences between the features of Exchange Online and Exchange Server:

Exchange ActiveSync (EAS) access to Exchange Web Services (EWS): This feature is supported by Exchange Server and Exchange Online.
Custom Information Rights Management templates: This feature is supported by Exchange Server and Exchange Online.
In-place eDiscovery & hold: This feature is supported by Exchange Server and Exchange Online.

Throttling is available for exchange on premise, accordinr to this articule
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/client-developer/exchange-web-services/ews-throttling-in-exchange
Correct answer

"no changes to EWS capabilities of on-premises Exchange products. "

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -

In the Microsoft 365 Device Management portal, which two blades should you use? To answer, select the appropriate options in the dialog box in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

discussion.content:

"choose Devices > Windows > Windows enrollment > Devices "

Answer is correct

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -
You are the Microsoft 365 administrator for a company. The company supports an aggressive rollout of features.
You need to release features as soon as they are released.
Which feature phase should you use for each development step? To answer, drag the appropriate feature phases to the correct development steps. Each feature phase may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Select and Place:
//IMG//

comments.content:
Are you sure??

Comliance is usually when general release. 
QA when public preview
Documentation when GA

Microsoft states that there are no compliance guarantees or SLA before GA

discussion.content:
Answer provided is correct

"company supports an aggressive rollout of features"

compliance is done after private as the first step
QA is done for public review as second step
Documentation is done at general availability at last step

I think answer is correct. 

In my opinion... 
>private - for compliance
>public - for compliance and QA
>GA - done compliance and QA and NOW ready for documentation

Answer is correct:
Development: Not available to the public 
Private preview: Available only to a selected audience
Public preview: Available to all customers
General availability (GA): Available to all customers

https://subscription.packtpub.com/book/cloud-and-networking/9781801073301/18/ch18lvl1sec38/azure-service-life-cycle#:~:text=The%20service%20life%20cycle%20and,preview%3A%20Available%20to%20all%20customers
Compliance testing is a process conducted to determine if a process, product, or service meets a set of requirements, based on internal or external standards or regulations so this should be Private.

comments.content:
wrong, GA is available for whole the public. You won't set it available for the whole public, when you are compliance testing. This will be done with a selected users. So answer is:
Private, Public and GA

discussion.content: GA, Private, Preview

Guys this should be 
GA
Private
Public
Correct answer

comments.content: Yes, but the Company supports aggressive rollout of features.

discussion.content:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/legal/supp-dynamics365-preview

"Previews are subject to reduced or different security, compliance and privacy commitments. Previews are not meant for production use, especially to process Personal Data or other data that is subject to heightened compliance requirements, and any use of “live” or production data is at your sole risk. Previews are not subject to any statements made on the Microsoft Trust Center."

The first one should be GA, not private preview
